The  Project  aims  to  support  the  Government’s  development 
objectives  that  give  priority  to  human  development,  poverty 
reduction,  and  environmental  protection.  The  Project will upgrade 
the  water  supply  systems  in  six  provincial  towns,  develop  a 
wastewater  collection  and  treatment  system  in  Sihanoukville, 
improve community sanitation conditions in selected communities, 
and help mobilize resources at the local government level.  
 
Water  supply  systems  and  environmental  sanitation  in  provincial 
towns deteriorated severely during the 1970s and 1980s because 
of  war,  ineffectual  management,  and  lack  of  maintenance.  The 
rapid  population  increase  in  urban  centers  has  aggravated  the 
situation. Inadequate potable water supply and sanitation systems 
have  resulted  in  deteriorating  environment  and  public  health 
conditions in the urban centers. Almost 20% of children die before 
reaching  the  age  of  five,  and  waterborne  diseases   account  for 
about 30% of hospitalizations. 
 
Cambodia’s  provincial  towns  serve  as  economic  centers  for  the 
rural areas and link the country's rural and urban economies. The 
towns  are  the  immediate  markets,  transportation  depots,  and 
processing  centers  for  agricultural  products  in  the  provinces. 
Improving  urban  services,  including  water  supply  and  sanitation, 
in the provincial towns will contribute to poverty reduction in both 
rural  and  urban  areas.  It  will  also  complement  other  social 
development  programs  such  as  primary  health.  In  addition,  the 
development  of  provincial  towns  will  help  absorb  the  rural 
migrants  and  reduce  pressures  on  the  urban  environment, 
infrastructure, and employment in the capital city of Phnom Penh. 
The Project is expected to bring about long-term positive social and 
environmental impacts.

Part  A:  Community  sanitation  and  health  awareness. 
Sanitation conditions in the poor communities in the Project towns 
will be improved through community education and participation in 
subproject  design,  cost  sharing,  and  operation  and  maintenance. 
About 3,500 households in the Project towns will benefit from the 
program.  
 
Part  B:  Water  supply.  Water  supply  in  Battambang,  Kampot, 
Kompong Cham, Kompong Thom, Pursat, and Svay Rieng will be

rehabilitation of the facilities for water intake and production, and 
replacement and extension of the reticulation networks.  
 
Part  C:  Wastewater  management.  A  sewage  collection  and 
treatment  system  with  a  capacity  of  5,700  cubic  meters  per  day 
will be designed and constructed in Sihanoukville.

essential structure for urban local governance will be studied and 
revenues at the local level improved.  
 
Part E: Implementation assistance.  The  assistance will cover: 
(i)  consulting  services  for  community  development,  engineering 
design,  construction  supervision,  and  project  management 
support; (ii) project administration equipment and facilities; and (iii) 
training.

III. 

BACKGROUND 

A. 

Economic Growth, Urbanization, and Poverty 

4. 
In  the  1990s,  Cambodia  was  transformed  from  an  agricultural  economy  to  one 
dominated  by  industry  and  services.  During  1990-2000,  the  share  of  agriculture  in  gross 
domestic  product  declined  from  about  51%  to  38%,  while  the  share  of  industry and services 
increased  from  49%  to  62%.  Along  with  the  economic  transformation,  rapid  urbanization  took 
place. The urban population growth rate peaked to 8.4% in the early 1990s before it declined to 
about 4% per annum. It is projected that up to 2005, the urban population will grow at an annual 
rate  of  around  3.4%,  compared  with  a  national  average  growth  rate  of  about  2.5%.  The  rapid 
increase of the urban population and dilapidated urban infrastructure, resulting from destruction

5. 
Poverty  is  pervasive  in  Cambodia.  Calculating  the  cost  of  food  and  nonfood 
requirements  in  Cambodia  in  1997,  the  Government  estimated  the  overall  poverty  line  to  be 
KR1,407 ($0.36) per capita per day in urban areas other than Phnom Penh. About 30% of the 
urban population in the provincial towns were living below the poverty line. One characteristic of 
Cambodian  urban  poverty  is  lack  of  access  to  basic  services  such  as  water  supply  and 
sanitation. 
 
B. 

Provincial Water Supply and Sanitation 

Most  urban  centers  suffer  from  poor  water  supply  and  sanitation.  Only  8.5%  of  the 
6. 
households in the provincial towns have access to private or public tap water, and 58% of the 
people  living  in  the  provincial  towns  draw  water  from  unprotected  sources.  About  58%  of  the 
households  living  in  these  towns  do  not  have  access  to  any  sanitation  facilities.  The  cost  of 
purchasing, treating, and storing water; the medical expenses for waterborne diseases; and lost 
productive time due to water fetching or illness are much higher to the poor as a percentage of 
their incomes. The socioeconomic survey conducted during the feasibility study  of the Project 
indicates that in the project towns residents without house connections pay 2.5–4 times higher 
for water than those with house connections.  
 
7. 
The  water  supply  systems  in  most  of  the  urban  centers  were  built  in  the  1920s  and 
1930s,  and  their  production  capacity  can  no  longer  meet  the  demand  of  today's  urban 
population. The treatment plants have fallen into disuse, the distribution systems are in disrepair 
with  average  leakage  rates  of  around  60%,  and  lack  of  pressure  in  the  pipelines has allowed 
polluted  groundwater  to  enter  the  water  supply  systems.  Insufficient  production  capacities, 
leaking distribution networks, and intermittent power supply limit water supply in most towns to a 
few  hours  per  day  and  to  limited  areas  only.  Major urban centers have combined stormwater 
and sewage drainage systems, which were constructed during the same period as those of the 
water  supply.  The  systems  have  no  treatment  facilities  and  were  basically  designed  to  drain 
only the commercial and market areas of towns. Untreated sewage flows into nearby rivers and 
water  bodies  and  polluted  the  environment.  The  haphazard  dumping  of  solid  waste  into  the 
drainage systems blocked the pipes and collection manholes.  
 
C. 

Government Policies and Plans 

8. 
The  Government  stated  in  its  first  5-year  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDP), 
1996–2000,  that  the  primary  objectives  of  its  development  strategy  are  to  reduce  poverty  and 
develop the country’s human resource base. The strategy emphasizes a balanced approach to 
rural development, assistance to the urban poor, and development of major urban growth poles. 
The  SEDP  accords  high  development  priority  to  water  supply  and  sanitation  in  urban  centers. 
The  Government’s  long-term  development  objectives  in  the  provincial  towns  are  to  supply 
affordable  water  that  meets  the  drinking  water  quality  standards,3  with  adequate  supply  to  at 
least  70%  of  the  provincial  urban  population.  The  long-term  objectives  for  sanitation  are  to 
enable  the  population  as  a  whole  to  have  access  to  environmental  sanitation  facilities,  and 
establish treatment for wastewater in all provincial towns.

Improving access of the poor to water supply and sanitation, and promoting sustainable 
9. 
management of the environment continue to be key  development strategies of SEDP II, 2001–
2005.  The  Government  will  promote  wider  provision  of  affordable  potable  water  supply  and 
sanitation,  as  it  contributes  broadly  to  tackling  the  causes  of  poverty  and  improving  public

the pollution of rivers.  
 
10. 
Since 1999, the Ministry of Industry, Mines, and Energy (MIME) has been working on an 
urban water supply policy. The policy calls for (i) a demand–responsive approach in developing 
new water supply systems in the urban centers, (ii) a wide range of private sector participation 
in  providing  the  services,  (iii)  full  cost  recovery  and  improvement  in  tariff  collection  efficiency, 
(iv) access  of  the  poor  to  improved  water  supply  systems,  (v)  financial  autonomy  of  public 
utilities,  and  (vi)  establishment  of  an  independent  regulator  for  the  water  supply  sector.  This 
policy  was  later  combined  with  the  rural  water  supply  and  sanitation  policy  and  became  the 
National  Policy  on  Water  Supply  and  Sanitation,  which  was  approved  by  the  Council  of 
Ministers  in  February  2003.  MIME  has  been  working  with  ADB,  World  Bank,  World  Health 
Organization  (WHO),  and  other  development  agencies  in  establishing  national  drinking  water 
quality  standards;  MIME  has  also  been  working,  with  assistance  from  the  World  Bank,  on 
setting  up  the  standards  for  designing  and  constructing  piped  water  supply  systems  in  both 
urban and rural areas, and on establishing a regulatory framework for the water supply sector.

11.

a  small-scale  TA  to  assess  the  needs  of  the  water  supply  and  sanitation  sectors.4  The  TA

E. 

Lessons Learned 

14.  Major lessons learned with regard to sustainable sector development  and timely project 
implementation  include  the  need  for  cost  recovery,  adequate  funding  for  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M), community participation and education, and institutional capacity building. 
A major cause of unsustainable projects in the sector, mostly assisted by external agencies, is 
lack  of  O&M  funds.  Actions  to  generate  adequate  financial  resources  for  project  O&M, 
especially  for  those  components  where  a  direct  user  charge  is  difficult  to  apply,  should  be 
identified  and  discussed  with  concerned  Government  agencies  during  policy  dialogue.  Great 
efforts  have  to  be  made  to  develop  a  feasible  cost  recovery  mechanism.  If  cost  recovery  is 
through indirect means such as development charges or local fees, management and auditing 
of the additional revenues and expenditure should be considered in the project design.  
 
15. 
The  ADB-financed  Phnom  Penh  Water  Supply  and  Drainage  Project  included  a 
community awareness and education program cofinanced by NORAD to encourage community 
participation  in  project  planning  and  implementation,  and  to  educate  the  urban  residents  on 
environmental sanitation matters. Initial success has led the Government and NORAD to agree 
to  expand  the  program's  coverage  and  extend  its  duration.  The  findings  of  the  program  are

A. 

Rationale 

18. 
It has been recognized that substantial improvement of the living standards of the rural 
poor, who account for 84% of the total population, is closely linked with economic development 
in urban centers. The expected benefits of rural development can be realized only if farmers are 
able  to  sell  their  increased  agricultural  produce  to  the  urban  economy  in  exchange  for  new 
farming  equipment,  fertilizer,  seeds,  technology,  and  better  consumption  goods.  Rural 
development,  therefore,  is  correlated  to  the  absorptive  capacity  of  the  urban  economy  for 
increased  rural  produce.  The  provincial  towns  serve  as  the  economic  centers  for  the  rural 
hinterland in the provinces, and the links between the rural and urban economies in the country. 
These  towns  are  the  immediate  markets,  transport  depots,  and  processing  centers  for 
agricultural produce from the provinces. They also provide part–time employment opportunities, 
and  hence  additional  income,  for  poor  farmers  during  the  slack  seasons.  Improving  urban 
services, including water supply and sanitation, in the provincial towns will therefore contribute 
to poverty reduction in both rural and urban areas. 
 
19. 
The selection of the project towns took into consideration the geographic concentration 
of  ADB’s  previous  assistance  and  the  economic  growth  potential,  the  status  of  cost  recovery, 
and  institutional  capabilities  of  the  provincial  towns.  Four  selected  towns?Svay  Rieng, 
Kompong Cham, Kampot, and Sihanoukville?are in areas under ADB’s first Rural Infrastructure 
Improvement Project.9 The three other towns?Battambang, Kompong Thom, and Pursat?are 
along the major national highways where ADB is the major multilateral development institution 
providing  financial  assistance.10  Battambang,  located  near  the  Cambodian-Thai  border  and 
along national highway No. 5, is the largest provincial town and has the potential to become the 
major  trade  center  in  the  northern  part  of  Cambodia.  The  seaport  and  tourist  resources  in 
Sihanoukville  make  it  the  fastest  growing  town  in  the  country.  Transport  services  and  tourism 
will continue contribute significantly to its economic growth. Kompong Cham is the capital town 
of  traditionally  the  richest  province  of  the  country  and  has  the  potential  to  become  the  major 
center  of  agro-industries.  With  the  improvement  of  the  highways  along  the  transportation 
corridor  connecting  Viet  Nam  and  Thailand,  economic  development  in  these  and  other  project 
towns is expected to take off rapidly.

THE PROPOSED SUPPLEMENTARY LOAN 

A. 

The Cost Overrun 

Compared  with  the  bidding  results,  the  cost  for  Part  B  (the  six-town  water  supply 
35. 
systems)  and  part  C  (wastewater  management  system  in  Sihanoukville)  was  substantially 
underestimated for the approved Project at appraisal, with the base cost for part B estimated at 
$10.8  million,  and  that  for  part  C  at  $5.6  million.  The  bidding  results  for  the  two  components 
showed the lowest bid price, net of contingencies, of $14.4 million for part B and $9.5 million for 
part C. The key factors contributing to the increase in cost are discussed in paras. 36-40.  
 

1. 

Provincial Towns Water Supply Systems 

36. 
A comparison of the winning bid and the cost estimates at appraisal shows a significant 
cost  increase  in  the  water  intake  and  treatment  facilities  in  Battambang,  Kampot,  Kompong 
Thom, and Pursat. While the feasibility study and appraisal assumed that the existing facilities 
could  be  rehabilitated  at  lower  cost,  the  design  consultants  recommended  reconstruction  of 
these  facilities  instead.  Apart  from  technical  considerations,  such  as  water  source  quality  and 
system  compatibility,  the  reconstructed  facilities  would  have  a  longer  useful  life  (50  years  if 

 10 

reconstructed  compared  with  15  years  if  rehabilitated),  and  higher  service  level  (100% 
compared with 60%). Therefore, the high capital cost for reconstruction would be a lower-cost 
solution  in  the  long  run.  Rehabilitation  at  low  capital  cost  was  preferred  during  the  feasibility 
study  and  appraisal  because  of  other  considerations:  political  instability  in  the  Government, 
economic  inactivity  in  the  provinces,  and  poor  institutional  and  financial  capabilities  at  the 
provincial waterworks. However, all these aspects have changed significantly since appraisal.  
 
37. 
Another major cause of the cost increase is the construction of generator and laboratory 
buildings and the provision of generators and laboratory equipment and chemicals in the project 
towns. The feasibility study anticipated that the provincial/municipal electrical supplies would be 
significantly  improved  to  provide  reliable  electrical  supplies  when  the  Project  is  completed. 
However, the electrical supplies are still unreliable in the project towns at the design stage, and 
the waterworks would need to install their own generators to ensure smooth operations of their 
water supply systems. The laboratory facilities were considered necessary at the design stage 
to  meet  the  increasing  demand  of  stakeholders  for  better  water  quality  monitoring  all  over  the 
country.  The  laboratories  would  also  be  useful  for  the  local  authorities  to  regulate  local  small 
and medium-sized food processing enterprises.  
 
38. 
A  change  in  the  chlorination  systems  also  contributes  to  the cost increase.  Presently, 
none of the project towns chlorinates its water supply, either because there is no chorine dosing 
system  in  place,  or  because  of  the  high  cost  of  chemicals  for  the  simple  calcium  hypochlorite 
dosing systems present in some project towns. The feasibility study recommended the provision 
or  repair  of  calcium  hypochlorite  dosing  systems.  However, 
the  design  consultants 
recommended  gas  chlorination  systems  instead,  which  are  more  expensive  in  capital 
investment, but have a much lower O&M cost and will be less expensive and more effective for 
the towns in the long run. 
 
39. 
Unit  costs  for  pipeline  construction  appear  to  have  risen  significantly  since  appraisal. 
Installation  of  pipes  in  the  size  range  most  frequently  employed  in  the  project  (100-200 
millimeter  in  diameter),  the  unit  cost  has  risen  by  over  50%.  Since  the  transmission  and 
distribution pipes typically represent a substantial percentage of the total value of a water supply 
system, such cost increases adversely affected the capital cost of the Project. Besides, the unit 
prices used at appraisal did not include separate categories for general items to be furnished by 
the contractor, such as securities, insurance, office facilities, etc. Such costs, when considered 
cumulatively, substantially increased the value of the contract. 
 

2. 

Sihanoukville Wastewater Management System 

40. 
A major cause of the cost overrun for the Sihanoukville wastewater management system 
is  the  change  in  the  diameters  of  trunk  sewers.  The  topographic  survey  conducted  during 
detailed  design  revealed  that,  to  keep  the  effluent  outlet  at  the  treatment  plant  at  a  level  high 
enough  to  accommodate  tidal  changes  and  flooding  levels,  the  slope  of  the  trunk  sewer  lines 
would be relatively flat (0.6 meter per 1,000 meter), which in turn requires pipelines with a much 
larger  diameter  (900  millimeter  vs  450  millimeter,  for  instance),  to  maintain  the  designed 
sewage  flows.  Along  with  the  change  in  the  size  of  the  trunk  sewers,  the  size  of  connector 
sewers was also adjusted to minimize the long-term investment cost. In addition, to maintain the 
flow  of  sewage  by  gravity  without  pumping  in  the  system,  embankment  is  needed  for  many 
portions of the pipelines.  
 
41. 
Another major cause of the cost overrun is replacement of the polyethylene lining of the 
anaerobic ponds with concrete lining, and the need to dig dewater trenches at the work site and 

 11 

provide  grouted  stone  and  clay  lining  for  the  facultative  and  maturation  ponds.  This  change  is 
necessary because the geotechnical investigation carried out during detailed design revealed a 
very  high  groundwater  table  throughout  the  project  area,  especially  at  the  treatment  plant  site 
(at  0.4-0.8  meter  in  depth),  and  aside  from  unconsolidated  sandy  soils  at  the  surface  layer 
(down to 1 meter in depth), there are loose silty sands at the treatment plant site. Other factors 
contributing to the cost overrun include: (i) the unit cost of the comparable pipes had increased 
by more than 50%, (ii) the domestic preference  had resulted in higher cost, and (iii) the winning 
bid has an unexpected high price for general items.

F. 

Supplementary Loan Policy Requirements 

54. 
Since the 1991 Peace Accord, the Cambodian economy has been rebuilt from the ruins 
of two decades of regional and domestic conflicts. While remarkable progress has been made in 
the  past  decade,  its  weak  and  underdeveloped  economic  base  still  cannot  provide  adequate 
foreign  exchange  to  meet  the  demand  for  consumption  and  investment.  Nor  can  it  generate 
sufficient  revenues  for  the  Government  to  rebuild  the  essential  economic  infrastructure  in  the 
country. Consequently, the country has been experiencing continued deficit in both external and 
fiscal accounts. Its development programs are largely financed by external funding agencies.  
 
55. 
The  Government  has  accorded  water  supply,  sanitation,  and  environmental  protection 
high  development  priority,  as  reflected  in  SEDP,  1996-2000,  and  SEDP  II,  2001-2005.  The 
plans  recognize  that  developing  water  supply  and  sanitation  contributes  positively  to  poverty 
reduction, and that environmental protection is essential for long-term sustainable development. 
For  these  reasons,  the  Government  has  reconfirmed  the  priority  of  the  Project  in  its 
development programs.  
 
Given  its  limited  domestic  resources,  the  Government  has  sought  additional  funding 
56. 
from  a  number  of  external  sources  to  finance  the  cost  overrun.  Due  to  the  urgency  of  the 
financing requirement, it has been difficult for the Government to receive the funding in the time 
frame  required  for  the  Project.  Although  the  Government  has  difficulty  in  providing  funding  for 
the cost overrun up-front, the Government and the EAs have committed to implement full cost 
recovery  for  the  investment.  MIME  has  agreed  with  ADB  to  gradually  introduce  the  required 
tariff increase in the six provincial towns to reach full cost recovery by the end of 2006. Similarly, 
MPWT  and  the  municipality  of  Sihanoukville  have  agreed  with  ADB  to  introduce  wastewater 
tariffs in the city to reach full cost recovery by the end of 2009.

1. 
The  original  economic  analysis  was  undertaken  in  1999  during  the  feasibility  study. 
Because of significant changes in the cost estimates between the feasibility study and detailed

Development  Bank's  (ADB)  Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects  (1997)  and 
Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Water  Supply  Projects  (1998). The  subprojects  are 
evaluated over a period of 25 years with no salvage value assumed thereafter. 
 
The  capital  costs  and  incremental  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  of  each 
2. 
subproject  were  considered.  Economic  costs  were  derived  from  the  financial  project costs. All 
costs are expressed in constant (2003) prices, and taxes and duties have been deducted from 
base costs. Economic costs were valued using the domestic price numeraire, but expressed in 
dollars.  Tradable  components  have  been  adjusted  to  economic  prices  using  a  shadow 
exchange  rate  factor  (SERF)1  and  nontradable  components  are  valued  at  domestic  market

B. 

Water Supply 

3. 
The  Project  will  directly  benefit  approximately  270,000  people  in  six  provincial  towns, 
namely: Battambang, Kampot, Kompong Cham, Kompong Thom, Pursat, and Svay Rieng. The 
appraisal  report  showed  that  all  households  including  those  with  piped  connections  in  the  six 
towns used a variety of sources of water throughout the year because of limited supply from the 
existing  systems.  The  construction  of  the  Project  will  remove  the  water  supply  limitations  and 
enable  more  households  to  be  connected  with  reliable  and  stable  piped  water  supply. 
Quantifiable  economic  benefits  from  improved  water  supply  include  nonincremental  water 
consumption,  valued  at  the  current  average  price  of  water  supply  from  nonpiped  sources 
ranging  from  KR1,400  per  cubic  meter  (m3)  to  KR2,500  per  m3;  and  incremental  water 
consumption, valued at the average demand price ranging from KR1,200 per m3 to KR1,850 per 
m3.  The  volume  of  nonincremental  water  consumption  and  incremental  water  consumption  for 
each  subproject  was  estimated  based  on  household  surveys  and  the  population  that  the 
subproject is going to serve.  
 
4. 
Resource cost  savings  are  also  expected  from  the  Project.  The  socioeconomic  survey 
showed  that  all  households  in  the  six  towns,  including  those  with  piped  connections,  were 
equipped with water storage facilities such as water tanks and jars to respond to the unstable 
and irregular water supply, and nearly a quarter of the households without piped connection had 
to spend 1–5 hours weekly to fetch water from sources other than a piped system. The reliable 
and stable water supply service provided by the Project will enable the households to get rid of 
the  water  storage  facility  and  stop  spending  time  in  fetching  water.  The  cost  savings  on  the 
water  storage  facility  and  time  savings,  estimated  from  the  household  survey,  range  from 
KR1,100 to KR5,000  and from KR2,200 to KR5,500 per person per year, respectively.

C. 

Sihanoukville Sewerage  

6. 
Sihanoukville, located on the Gulf of Thailand, is a recognized tourism center with many 
natural  advantages, particularly  four  beautiful beaches and  one  attractive  island. The coastal 
city  has  been  enjoying  dramatic  tourist  growth  in  the  past  5  years,  with  an  average  annual 
growth  rate  of  more  than  35%  (70%  for  international  tourists).  With  approximately  120,000 
tourist  arrivals  in  2002,  including  20,000  international  tourist  arrivals,  and  about  1,300  hotel 
rooms,  Sihanoukville  has  become  a  leading  coastal  resort  that  attracts  tourists  traveling  from 
Viet  Nam,  Thailand,  and  Singapore.  While  the  booming  tourism  has  brought  growth  and 
employment to the city, it has also produced an increasing amount of wastewater that has been 
discharged into the open sea close to the beaches, polluting the very resources that have been 
the  tourist  attractions  of  the  city,  and  posing  health  hazards  to  the  recreational  users  of  the 
beaches. The problem will become more acute in the near future with increasing tourist arrivals 
and the completion of an urban water supply project in 2005.  
 
The  Project  will  provide  a  reticulated  sewerage  system  in  the  central  area  and  major 
7. 
tourist  destinations  of  Sihanoukville  and  a  treatment  plant  that  uses  the  stabilization  ponds 
process.  This  treatment  process  was  considered  the  least-cost  solution,  both  at  appraisal and 
reappraisal,  compared  with  other  wastewater  treatment  technologies.  It  is  suitable  for

Sihanoukville where land cost is low and skilled technicians are rare. It has the advantage of low 
capital  and  O&M  cost,  relatively  high  biological  oxygen  demand  conversion,  and  minimum 
operational  skills  required.  The  treatment  plant  is  located  on  vacant  land  far  from  the  town 
center and residential areas; therefore, the environmental impact of bad odors from the ponds is 
negligible.  Because  power  supply  is  expensive  and  unreliable  in  Cambodia,  the  sewage 
collection, reticulation, and transmission will be gravity-fed with no pumping to minimize energy 
consumption in operating the system. 
 
The major economic benefits expected  from the subproject are tourism benefits arising 
8. 
from (i) increased number of tourists visiting  Sihanoukville, and (ii) increased daily spending by 
tourists.  The  analysis  considers  mainly the  benefits from foreign tourists,  as  net  spending  by 
local tourists is marginal compared with that of foreign tourists.  
 
9. 
The tourism benefits attributable to the subproject are the increased net expenditure of 
foreign  tourists  and  its  multiplier  effects  on  the  country’s  economy,  which  are  induced  by  the 
project and retained by the country.  The net  expenditure of tourists,  estimated  at  30% of their 
gross expenditure, is the difference between the  tourists’ gross expenditure on tourism services 
and  the  costs  of  providing  such  services.  The  analysis  takes  50%  of  the  project-induced 
incremental net expenditure of tourists as the benefits arising directly from the subproject and a 
factor of 0.9 is used to adjust this net expenditure to the benefits of the country after considering 
the leakage and multiplier effects of tourism benefits in the Mekong region.3 
 
10. 
The without-project scenario assumes wastewater will continue to flow untreated to the 
sea. The tourist’s interest to visit Sihanoukville will be impaired by the increasing pollution of the 
beaches  which  are  the  main  tourist  attractions.  This  scenario  assumes  tourist  growth  will 
gradually slow down from the current 35% to 8% in 2024, and the average tourist stay will be 
reduced by half a day. The with-project scenario assumes that tourist growth will slow down but 
at a more gradual rate, the average tourist stay will remain at 3.5 days, and tourist spending will 
increase slightly by $1.5 per day to accommodate the wastewater treatment charges to hotels 
and restaurants which will be passed on to the tourists, who will be more willing to consume due
